Subject: How can geometric relationship be exploited in virtual creature controllers?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=345796568; y=Vvmv0HqCygxTuWmn_kvo2-qcMQs_3ehumr58YekiUk0BXTNaIENH3k4v

In other words, how do you configure a substrate for hyperneat for a
list o=
f inputs that correspond to joint angles and velocities and a
list of outpu=
ts that correspond to the desired joint state (i.e. hold,
relax, extend, or=
 contract)?

Vinod K. Valsalam wrote an excellent paper on making modular
s=
ubnetworks in order to take advantage of a symmetrical configuration
of leg=
s, as in a quadruped trot, bound, pace or "pronk". This sounds
like a good =
idea, but in the case of a biped or humanoid creature (for
example, the rag=
doll rig I'm currently working on has 20 1-dof
joints), I'm not sure I want=
 to limit myself from exploring behavior
that isn't strictly modular with r=
espect to the limb. Symmetry is only
bilateral in a humanoid, you won't ach=
ieve as dramatic a reduction in
search space as you do with 4 or more symme=
trical limbs by
compartmentalizing it that way.

So the question is, how do=
 I lay out my ragdoll model in the substrate
if I want to take advantage of=
 the geometric relationship between the
joints in the body?
